canonical_explanation.text: Data interpretation means reading graphs and tables to answer questions and draw conclusions. From bar graphs, we read bar heights to find values. From pictographs, we count symbols and multiply by the key. We can identify the highest, lowest, and compare values. We can find totals, differences, and make simple conclusions about what the data shows.
rules: Read bar heights carefully against the scale
In pictographs, count symbols and multiply by key value
Identify highest (tallest bar/most symbols) and lowest values
Find totals by adding all values
Draw conclusions: which is most/least popular, any trends
Always check the title, labels, and key before answering

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, the tallest bar represents the category with the:
questions.explanation_correct: The tallest bar has the greatest frequency/value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tallest bar = highest frequency = greatest value.

questions.question_text: Bar graph shows favourite sports: Cricket-35, Football-25, Hockey-15, Tennis-10, Badminton-20. The most popular sport:
questions.explanation_correct: Cricket has the highest value (35), so it is the most popular sport.

questions.question_text: Using the same sports data, the least popular sport:
questions.explanation_correct: Tennis has the lowest value (10), making it the least popular.

questions.question_text: Using the same sports data, how many more students prefer cricket over football?
questions.explanation_correct: Cricket (35) - Football (25) = 10 more students.

questions.question_text: Using the same sports data, total number of students surveyed:
Pictograph: Key = 1 star = 5 books. Reading: 6 stars, Maths: 4 stars, Science: 5 stars. How many books in all?
questions.explanation_correct: Total symbols = 6+4+5 = 15. Total books = 15 × 5 = 75.

questions.question_text: Using the same pictograph, which subject has the most books?
questions.explanation_correct: Reading has 6 stars (30 books), the most among all subjects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reading (6 stars = 30 books) has the most.

questions.question_text: Using the same pictograph, the difference between Reading and Maths books:
questions.explanation_correct: Reading: 6×5=30. Maths: 4×5=20. Difference: 30-20=10 books.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows ice cream sales: Summer-80, Monsoon-30, Winter-20, Spring-50. Which conclusion is correct?

options.text: More ice cream is sold in cold weather
Summer has the highest ice cream sales
Sales are the same in all seasons

questions.explanation_correct: Summer (80) has the highest bar, meaning the most ice cream is sold in summer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Summer (80) > Spring (50) > Monsoon (30) > Winter (20). Summer is highest.

questions.question_text: From the ice cream data above, we can conclude that people prefer ice cream more in hot weather.
questions.explanation_correct: Summer (hot) has 80 sales while winter (cold) has only 20. This suggests ice cream is more popular in hot weather.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Summer (80) >> Winter (20) shows that hot weather = more ice cream sales.

questions.question_text: Bar graph - books read by students: Aman-8, Bina-12, Chetan-5, Deepa-10, Esha-7. Who read the most?
questions.explanation_correct: Bina read 12 books, the highest among all students.

questions.question_text: Using the same data, how many books did all 5 students read together?
questions.explanation_correct: 8+12+5+10+7=42 books total.

questions.question_text: Pictograph - flowers in a garden. Key: 1 flower = 10. Roses: 5 flowers, Lilies: 3.5 flowers, Daisies: 4 flowers. How many lilies?
questions.explanation_correct: 3.5 symbols × 10 = 35 lilies.

questions.question_text: Using the flower data above, which flower should the gardener plant more of if she wants equal numbers?
questions.explanation_correct: Roses: 50, Daisies: 40, Lilies: 35. Lilies have the fewest, so plant more lilies to equalize.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lilies (35) have the fewest. To equalize, plant more lilies.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows class test scores: Class A-75, Class B-82, Class C-68, Class D-90, Class E-78. Which class performed best?
questions.explanation_correct: Class D scored 90, the highest among all classes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Class D (90) = tallest bar = best performance.

questions.question_text: Using the class test data, the average score of the 5 classes is ___.
Pictograph: Favourite drinks. Key: 1 cup = 8 students. Tea: 4 cups, Coffee: 3 cups, Juice: 5 cups, Milk: 6 cups. Total students:
questions.explanation_correct: Total cups = 4+3+5+6 = 18. Total students = 18 × 8 = 144.

questions.question_text: From the drinks data, what fraction of students prefer Milk?
questions.explanation_correct: Milk: 6 cups out of 18 = 6/18 = 1/3. Or 48 out of 144 = 48/144 = 1/3. All are equivalent.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows rainfall (mm): Jan-10, Feb-20, Mar-25, Apr-40, May-60. Which two months together equal the rainfall of May?
questions.explanation_correct: Feb (20) + Apr (40) = 60 mm, which equals May's rainfall.

questions.question_text: What can we conclude from increasing rainfall Jan to May?

options.text: It rains more as summer approaches

questions.explanation_correct: The data shows increasing rainfall from January to May, suggesting more rain as months progress toward the rainy season.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rainfall goes from 10 to 60, showing an increasing trend toward warmer months.

questions.question_text: To compare two categories in a bar graph, we compare the heights of their bars.
questions.explanation_correct: Bar heights directly show values. Taller bar = greater value.

questions.question_text: Pictograph: Cars sold. Key: 1 car = 50. Jan: 3 cars, Feb: 5 cars, Mar: 4 cars. How many MORE cars were sold in Feb than Jan?
A bar graph shows library visits: Mon-45, Tue-30, Wed-50, Thu-25, Fri-40. On which day should the library add extra staff?
questions.explanation_correct: Wednesday has the most visitors (50), so extra staff would help manage the crowd.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Busiest day (Wednesday, 50 visitors) needs extra staff.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows money saved by Rina each month: Jan-Rs 100, Feb-Rs 150, Mar-Rs 200, Apr-Rs 250, May-Rs 300. Her total savings:
From Rina's savings data, what is the pattern?

options.text: She saves the same each month
She saves Rs 50 more each month

questions.explanation_correct: 100, 150, 200, 250, 300 — each month increases by Rs 50.

questions.question_text: Pictograph key: 1 symbol = 20. If 'March' shows 7 symbols, March value = ___.
Bar graph: Heights of 5 plants (cm): A-12, B-18, C-15, D-20, E-10. Range of plant heights (tallest minus shortest):
questions.explanation_correct: Tallest: D (20). Shortest: E (10). Range = 20-10 = 10 cm.

questions.question_text: When a bar graph shows equal bars for two categories, those categories have the same frequency.
questions.explanation_correct: Equal bar heights mean equal frequencies/values for those categories.

questions.question_text: Pictograph: Fruits sold. Key: 1 fruit picture = 15 kg. Mango: 8 pictures, Apple: 5 pictures, Banana: 10 pictures. How many kg of fruits were sold in total?
questions.explanation_correct: Total pictures = 8+5+10 = 23. Total kg = 23 × 15 = 345 kg.

questions.question_text: Bar graph: Number of students in each section. A-42, B-38, C-45, D-40. Average students per section:
A graph shows student attendance: Mon-90%, Tue-85%, Wed-95%, Thu-80%, Fri-75%. On which day should the teacher investigate why attendance was low?
questions.explanation_correct: Friday has the lowest attendance (75%), so the teacher should investigate.

questions.question_text: Two bars in a graph are very close in height (48 and 50). What should you do to compare them accurately?

options.text: Read the exact values from the scale

questions.explanation_correct: When bars are close in height, read the exact values from the y-axis scale for accurate comparison.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Use the scale to read exact values when bars look similar.

questions.question_text: Pictograph key: 1 symbol = 4. If Category A has 3 full symbols and 1 half symbol, the value is:
If a bar graph shows boys = 25 and girls = 30 in a class, the percentage of boys is ___%.
questions.explanation_correct: Total = 55. Boys percentage = (25/55) × 100 ≈ 45.45 ≈ 45%.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows weekly production: Week 1-200, Week 2-250, Week 3-180, Week 4-300. Which week had a drop in production?
questions.explanation_correct: Week 3 (180) dropped from Week 2 (250). It had lower production than the previous week.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, if half a symbol represents 3 items, one full symbol represents:
questions.explanation_correct: If half = 3, then full = 3 × 2 = 6 items.

questions.question_text: A graph shows that City A has 200 parks and City B has 50 parks. Which conclusion is correct?

options.text: City A has 4 times as many parks as City B
City A has 2 times as many parks

questions.explanation_correct: 200 ÷ 50 = 4. City A has 4 times as many parks as City B.

questions.question_text: You need to read the scale carefully before interpreting a bar graph.
questions.explanation_correct: The scale determines the actual values. Without reading it correctly, you may misinterpret the data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Always check the scale, labels, and title before drawing conclusions.

questions.question_text: A graph shows: Math test scores went from 60 in Term 1 to 85 in Term 3. A good conclusion:
questions.explanation_correct: Scores went from 60 to 85 — an increase of 25 marks, showing improvement.

questions.question_text: Pictograph: Votes for class monitor. Key: 1 star = 2 votes. Arjun: 8 stars, Meera: 10 stars, Ravi: 6 stars. Who won?
questions.explanation_correct: Meera: 10×2=20 votes (most). Arjun: 16. Ravi: 12. Meera won.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meera (10 stars = 20 votes) has the most votes.

questions.question_text: Bar graph of daily visitors to a museum: Mon-120, Tue-150, Wed-100, Thu-180, Fri-200, Sat-350, Sun-400. Weekend visitors total:
questions.explanation_correct: Weekend = Saturday + Sunday = 350 + 400 = 750.

questions.question_text: From the museum data, what can we conclude about weekends?

options.text: More people visit on weekends than weekdays
The same number visit every day
The museum is closed on weekends

questions.explanation_correct: Weekend total (750) vs weekday average (150). Weekends clearly have more visitors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weekend days (350, 400) have far more visitors than weekdays (100-200).

questions.question_text: If a bar graph shows value 35 for one category and 20 for another, the difference is ___.
Pictograph: Trees planted. Key: 1 tree = 25. Class 3: 4 trees, Class 4: 6 trees, Class 5: 8 trees. Class 5 planted how many more than Class 3?
A bar graph can help us predict future trends.
questions.explanation_correct: By observing patterns in a bar graph (e.g., consistently increasing values), we can make predictions about future trends, though they aren't guaranteed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Patterns in data can suggest trends, helping us predict what might happen next.

questions.question_text: Bar graph: Marks of 4 students - Asha-78, Bala-92, Charu-85, Dev-90. How many students scored above 80?
questions.explanation_correct: Bala (92), Charu (85), Dev (90) all scored above 80. That's 3 students.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, 1 symbol = 100 people. If a city has 5.5 symbols, its population represented is:
A graph shows that sales of umbrellas peak in July and August. A likely reason is:

options.text: It is the monsoon/rainy season in India

questions.explanation_correct: July-August is the monsoon season in India, so people buy more umbrellas due to rain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: July-August = Indian monsoon = high umbrella demand.

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, if two bars have a big gap in height, it means:

options.text: There is a large difference between the values

questions.explanation_correct: A large difference in bar heights indicates a significant difference in the values they represent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Big height difference = big value difference.

questions.question_text: Before answering questions about a graph, you should first look at:

options.text: The title, axis labels, and scale/key

questions.explanation_correct: Always read the title (what the graph shows), axis labels (what is being measured), and scale/key (what values the bars/symbols represent) before interpreting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Title + labels + scale/key = essential first steps in reading any graph.
